In Haiti, giant earthmovers are tearing away at the rubble from last month's devastating earthquake.
It's a sign the recovery process is under way.
But as NPR's Tamara Keith tells us in this Reporter's Notebook, people are still afraid to go indoors.
There are plenty of buildings standing in Port-au-Prince.
They weren't all destroyed.
Some have barely a noticeable crack.
But no one trusts them.
And why should they, when so many cement structures that seemed so sturdy turned to dust in moments?
(Soundbite of conversations)
I met Francoise Timo as it was just getting dark.
She was sitting on lawn furniture on the sidewalk in front of her house.
Her 75-year-old mom was there too, both of her arms in casts.
Their house looks perfectly fine.
But every night, they roll out a carpet on the sidewalk here and try to sleep.
During the day, they pretty much stay outside, too.
(Through translator) Like, we don't stay inside but we run every time that we are going inside.
Like if we want to go to the bathroom, we run and then do it quickly, and then run out.
Even some barbershops have moved outdoors.
(Soundbite of traffic)
Luxon Fanfan is giving one of his regular customers a tight trim on a street corner.
He pulled his clippers out of the rubble of what was once his barbershop, and is using car batteries for power.
(Through translator) People have been offering me some cement houses to use for my barbershop.
But I refuse.
If I find something wood, maybe I will go indoors.
His customers seem happier outside, anyway.
For so many people now, home is a tent made of sticks and cotton sheets.
Mary Celia Joseph lives in a tent camp at a park in Petionville.
